Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Lynchpin Global: An Immersive Massive Multi-Player Environment for Learning Effective Team-Based Project Management for Information Technology in Manufacturing Envi
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project enables users to rehearse the Project Management skills in the context of implementing enterprise business IT systems, such as ERP, using 3D Virtual World platforms. Participants interact with virtual replicas of actual manufacturing processes and products. They must solve a number of interacting problems, in a team setting, amidst real world production and performance demands (e.g. gathering information through site visits, developing ERP reports, delegating roles and negotiating scope changes). The method has shown success with IBM project managers as a model of immersive, simulation based, outcomes driven learning and training for organizations tackling large IT implementation efforts. However, these participants were already near expert level learners. Our objectives for this grant are to apply the method in an educational setting, deploying the method among novice to advanced beginner learners, as well as resolve a number of questions about the value of delivering such an experience within emerging Virtual Worlds platforms. We anticipate that Virtual Worlds will provide an optimal simulation-based rehearsal environment for training the next generation of project managers who will be facing increasingly complex implementation efforts that require agility and skill sets that go beyond current training methods.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project addresses the long-standing problem of high IT implementation failure rates among large organizations. Using an immersive, simulation-based, outcomes driven rehearsal methodology, this product has the potential to 1) increase the success rate of ERP systems in manufacturing environments, 2) by allowing users to rehearse and test deployment plans without risk and 3) and by providing students new to project management and IT implementation an opportunity to encounter real world problems and develop solutions under pressure in an immersive, experiential manner. Because we use Virtual Worlds as the rehearsal platform, this product will also test a number of questions about the feasibility of using Virtual Worlds technologies for rehearsing IT implementation efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the development of a virtual world approach which enables users to rehearse the Project Management skills in the context of implementing enterprise business IT systems, such as ERP or other enterprise business software.  The environment houses virtual 3D version of actual manufacturing companies; participants log into the world from any location and work together as a team.  Participants must solve a number of interacting problems, in a team setting, amidst real world production and performance demands (e.g. gathering information through site visits, developing ERP reports, delegating roles and tasks, and negotiating scope changes).  

Our method has shown success with our clients as a model of immersive, simulation based, outcomes driven learning and training for organizations tackling large IT implementation efforts. However, the participants were already near expert level learners. Our objective here was to develop an application for educational purposes, deploying the method among novice to advanced beginner learners. Virtual Worlds have the potential to provide an optimal simulation-based rehearsal environment for training the next generation of project managers who will be facing increasingly complex implementation efforts that require agility and skill sets that go beyond current training methods.

This tool addresses the long-standing problem of high IT implementation failure rates among large organizations.  Using an immersive, simulation-ased, outcomes driven rehearsal methodology, this product has the potential to 1) increase the success rate of ERP systems in manufacturing environments, 2) by allowing users to rehearse and test deployment plans without risk and 3) and by providing students new to project management and IT implementation an opportunity to encounter real world problems and develop solutions under pressure in an immersive, experiential manner.

Because we use Virtual Worlds as the rehearsal platform, this product will also test a number of questions about the feasibility of using Virtual Worlds technologies for rehearsing IT implementation efforts.

We were able to successfully import a model of an actual auto parts company and its processes into two different virtual world platforms with identical functionality (ERP systems working, ordering and assembly operations and financial tracking the results) and develop GUI interfaces for instructors to tailor the ongoing events to represent various levels of difficulty.  In addition, we developed the product so that the user can decide what kinds of objects the client’s business makes and sells.  For our working example, we used auto-parts, but by pointing the automated ordering and assembly capability to different 3D drawings, the product types can be changed instantly.  Below are some screenshots of our two working prototypes, the GUI for set up and some paper materials that students can use.

Since the project ended, we were able to get the approach to work in two more of the major virtual world platforms; we believe that platform agility is key to the success of this project.  We are now in discussion with several companies about using the product for their internal project management education for IT.
